title: Natural Law to Natural Liberty: 2,300 Years of Classical Liberal Thought
description: The complete intellectual genealogy of classical liberal economics and political philosophy, from ancient Greek virtue ethics through medieval natural law, Scottish Enlightenment moral philosophy, to Austrian economics.
curatedBy: Embassy of the Free Mind Collection

conceptualThreads.name: Natural Order/Harmony
conceptualThreads.evolution: Plato (Forms) → Aristotle (teleology) → Stoics (logos) → Aquinas (natural law) → Grotius (sociability) → Hutcheson (beauty/harmony/order) → Smith (invisible hand) → Hayek (spontaneous order)

conceptualThreads.name: Virtue & Flourishing
conceptualThreads.evolution: Aristotle (eudaimonia) → Cicero (Stoic virtue) → Aquinas (cardinal virtues) → Hutcheson (moral sense) → Smith (moral sentiments)

conceptualThreads.name: Law Without Legislation
conceptualThreads.evolution: Brehon Law (customary order) → Aristotle (natural vs conventional law) → Hume (justice as artificial virtue) → Smith (order without design) → Hayek (spontaneous order, law without legislation)

conceptualThreads.name: Property & Exchange
conceptualThreads.evolution: Aristotle (defense of private property) → Aquinas (natural law basis) → Locke (labor theory) → Smith → Ricardo → Austrian school

sections.title: Medieval Synthesis (1270)
keyConcepts: Natural law as participation in eternal law

researchValue: This collection enables tracing the complete intellectual genealogy of classical liberal economic and political philosophy. Researchers can follow specific conceptual threads (natural law, virtue ethics, spontaneous order, property rights) across 2,300 years, observing how ancient ideas evolved through medieval synthesis, early modern secularization, Scottish moral philosophy, into modern economic theory.
